Office of Science
Report Date: March 2016
 Mercury is a chemical element with symbol Hg and atomic number 80. It is commonly known as quicksilver and was formerly named hydrargyrum (/ha?dr?'?rd???r?m/).[5] A heavy, silvery d-block element, mercury is the only metallic element that is liquid at standard conditions for temperature and pressure; the only other element that is liquid under these conditions is the halogen bromine, though metals such as caesium, gallium, and rubidium melt just above room temperature.[6][7] Mercury occurs in deposits throughout the world mostly as cinnabar (mercuric sulfide). The red pigment vermilion is obtained by grinding natural cinnabar or synthetic mercuric sulfide.
Mercury is used in thermometers, barometers, manometers, sphygmomanometers, floats, mercury switches, mercury relays, fluorescent lamps and other devices, though concerns about the element's toxicity have led to mercury thermometers and sphygmomanometers being largely phased out in clinical environments in favor of alternatives such as alcohol- or galinstan-filled glass thermometers and thermistor- or infrared-based electronic instruments.[8] Mercury is also used in fluorescent lighting.[9] Electricity passed through mercury vapor in a fluorescent lamp produces short-wave ultraviolet light, which then causes the phosphor in the tube to fluoresce, producing visible light.
Mercury poisoning can result from exposure to water-soluble forms of mercury (such as mercuric chloride or methylmercury), by inhalation of mercury vapor, or by eating seafood contaminated with mercury.[10] Mercury is a heavy metal that is particularly harmful to neurodevelopment.
Atmospheric pressure does not change the melting point of mercury. Mercury's melting point is -38.83 degrees Celsius at standard pressure.

user_query: about how big is the international space station ?
text-davinci-002_response:
The International Space Station (ISS) is a modular space station (habitable artificial satellite) in low Earth orbit. The ISS programme is a joint project between five participating space agencies: NASA (United States), Roscosmos (Russia), JAXA (Japan), ESA (Europe), and CSA (Canada). The ownership and use of the space station is established by intergovernmental treaties and agreements. The station serves as a microgravity and space environment research laboratory in which crew members conduct experiments in biology, human biology, physics, astronomy, meteorology, and other fields. The ISS is suited for the testing of spacecraft systems and equipment required for missions to the Moon and Mars.
The ISS consists of pressurised modules, external trusses, solar arrays, and other components. ISS modules measure approximately 4 metres (13 ft) in diameter and are arranged in an elongated structure. The station has a total internal pressurised volume of 916 cubic metres (32,100 cu ft), making it slightly larger than a Soyuz spacecraft. The U.S. Orbital Segment (USOS) of the ISS consists of six pressurised modules: two node modules, a unity module, a laboratory module, a living quarters module, and an airlock module. Roscosmos' Zvezda service module is the structural and functional center of the Russian Orbital Segment (ROS) and houses the main living quarters for the crew, propulsion, waste management, and life support systems.
The ISS is the largest human-made body in low Earth orbit and can often be seen with the naked eye from Earth. With a mass of about 450,000 kilograms (990,000 lb), the ISS orbits at an altitude of between 330 and 435 kilometres (205 and 270 mi) by means of reboosts using the engines of the Zvezda service module or visiting spacecraft. It completes 15.54 orbits per day.
The ISS has a diameter of approximately 110 metres (360 ft). It is about the size of a football field including the end zones.
